document_title: Parkinson's disease: Causes, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Parkinson's disease is a neurological disease, manifested by a degenerative disorder of the central nervous system that causes cells in the brain to degenerate and lack dopamine. People with Parkinson's disease don't have enough of the chemical dopamine in their brain because some of the nerve cells that produce dopamine have died. (first)
The disease causes movement disorders, causing patients to have difficulty moving, maintaining balance and muscle control. People with Parkinson's disease may even lose some normal physical functions.
About 10 million people suffer from this neurological disease worldwide, of which in the UK, the number of people "living" with Parkinson's disease is about 145,000 people. In Vietnam, there are about 6.1 million people with Parkinson's disease, accounting for 1% of the total population. The death rate of people with Parkinson's disease is also relatively high, increasing 2.16 times in 2016 alone and is showing increasing signs. (2)
About 10 million people have Parkinson's disease worldwide
